questions.text: A trial is being conducted to determine the efficacy of a myofilament calcium sensitizer in patients with heart failure. Which among the following is the drug likely being studied?
questions.solution:
Levosimendan is a myofilament calcium senstizer. 

Calcium sensitizers bind and induce a conformational change in thin-filament regulatory protein troponin C. Thus increasing the sensitivity of contractile myofilaments to calcium. The result is an increased force of contraction for a given cytosolic calcium concentration. 

Option B: Omapatrilat is a dual ACE and neprilysin inhibitor that failed clinical trials due to increased risk of angioedema. 

Option C: Sacubitril is a neprilysin inhibitor approved in combination with valsartan for CHF. 

Option D: Enoximone is a PDE-3 inhibitor.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in heart failure

Drugs used in acute decompensated heart failure:
 
Intravenous vasodilators

Nitroglycerine

Sodium nitroprusside

 Decrease preload and afterload
Nesiritide Recombinant human BNP
 
Intravenous positive inotropes

Dobutamine

Dopamine

Epinephrine

Norepinephrine

 β1 receptor-mediated stimulation of cardiac output

Enoximone

Milrinone

 PDE 3/4 inhibitors

Levosimendan

Pimobendan

 Combined Ca2+ sensitizers and PDE3 inhibitors
 
Drugs used for rapid symptom relief

Bumetanide

Furosemide

Torasemide

 Loop diuretics- used for symptomatic treatment of severe heart failure and acute decompensation.
Morphine Opioid - to calm the patient and decreases cardiac O2 consumption
 
Drugs used in chronic heart failure:
Drugs Uses
ACE inhibitors Used as first-line therapy
ARBs Used in case of intolerance to ACE inhibitors
Beta-blockers Used as first-line therapy  

Spironolactone

Eplerenone

 Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists - first-line drugs for symptomatic heart failure.
SGLT-2 inhibitors Used as 1st line therapy- reduces mortality and morbidity
Sacubitril/Valsartan Neprilysin inhibitor/ARB(ARNI)
Ivabradine Inhibitor of If current in the sinoatrial node

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presented with a firm, non-tender scrotal mass. He was previously treated surgically for undescended testes. Immunohistochemistry was positive for KIT, OCT 3/4, and podoplanin. AFP was negative, and serum androgens were normal. Ultrasound revealed a homogenous, hypoechoic intratesticular mass. What is the histopathological finding likely to be seen?

AFP - alpha feto protein

choices.text: Derivatives of all three germ layers

questions.solution:
The clinical case and the history of cryptorchidism point to the diagnosis of seminoma. Histopathological finding seen in seminoma is a 'fried egg appearance' of cells.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor peaking in the fourth decade. It is the equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. A history of cryptorchidism increases the risk of developing seminoma.

Generally, it presents as a nodule or painless swelling of the testis. Sometimes, there might be the presence of a dull ache or heavy sensation in the lower abdomen, or scrotum. It can metastasize to many organs like the lymph nodes, lungs, brain, and gastrointestinal tract.

It is evaluated initially by laboratory tests and ultrasound scans. Serum tumor markers including alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (beta-HCG), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), are measured. Placental alkaline phosphatase can also be elevated. AFP is not elevated in pure seminomas. An ultrasound scan shows a homogeneous hypoechoic intratesticular mass. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin while it is negative for cytokeratin.

Grossly, the testis has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis as shown below.

The histological examination shows sheets of uniform cells with clear or watery cytoplasm with varying amounts of glycogen. A large central nucleus, with one or two prominent nucleoli, contributes to the 'fried egg appearance'. These sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa, containing lymphocytic infiltrate. The below image shows the histological picture of a seminoma.

Other options:

Option B: Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors and resemble endodermal sinuses. They resemble glomerulus-like structures in the visceral and parietal layer while the central core consists of capillaries. It is commonly seen in children and infants up to 3 years of age. AFP is positive. The image of Schiller Duval bodies is shown below. 

Option C: Crystalloids of Reinke are seen in Leydig cell tumors. They are rod-shaped crystalloids seen in the cytoplasm of neoplastic Leydig cells. They are commonly seen in children or adults. Features include testicular swelling and gynecomastia. Serum androgens and estrogens are elevated. The image of Reinke crystals is shown below.

Option D: Teratoma can be seen in infants and children after yolk sac tumors. It consists of derivatives of all three germ layers. It includes islands of bronchial epithelium, neural tissue, muscle, islands of cartilage, clusters of squamous epithelium, etc. Ultrasonography will show a heterogeneous mass with echogenic foci due to the presence of calcification, sebum, and hair. 

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text: A 46-year-old male patient was treated with haloperidol for delirium. He then developed fever, tachycardia, increased blood pressure, and muscle stiffness and showed agitation and an altered mental status. Investigations revealed elevated levels of creatine phosphokinase. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The abovementioned clinical features in a patient who has been administered haloperidol are suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) is a life-threatening adverse effect to antipsychotics with a predilection in males. Young patients are affected more commonly than elderly patients. Haloperidol poses the highest risk for NMS.

NMS is characterized by increased pulse and blood pressure; motor and behavioral symptoms such as muscular rigidity and dystonia, akinesia, and agitation; and autonomic symptoms like hyperthermia. Laboratory findings include an increased white blood cell count and increased levels of creatine phosphokinase, plasma myoglobin, and myoglobinuria.

The condition may occur within 24–72 hours after initiation of the treatment, and if untreated, may last for 10 to 14 days.

Treatment includes the administration of dantrolene, bromocriptine, and sometimes, amantadine. Bromocriptine and amantadine pose direct DRA effects and may serve to overcome the antipsychotic-induced dopamine receptor blockade. Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) has also been used for its management.

Other options:

Option A: Serotonin syndrome occurs due to concurrent administration of an SSRI with an MAO-inhibitor, L-tryptophan, or lithium, which can raise plasma serotonin concentrations to toxic levels. This serious and possibly fatal syndrome with symptoms in order of appearance - diarrhea, restlessness; extreme agitation, hyperreflexia, rapid fluctuations in vitals; myoclonus, hyperthermia, uncontrollable shivering, and rigidity; and eventually delirium, status epilepticus, cardiovascular collapse, and death. 

Option B: Tardive dyskinesia is characterized by abnormal, irregular, involuntary choreoathetoid movements of the muscles of the head, limbs, and trunk. Perioral movement is the most common. The condition usually develops as a delayed response to antipsychotics, about 6 months after treatment.

Option C: Hypersensitivity reaction to haloperidol presents as a typical anaphylactic reaction with angioedema, facial and laryngeal edema, rash, urticaria, bronchospasm, and laryngospasm.

Related Pearl: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Neuroleptic Malignant syndrome
Signs/ symptoms

Fever (sometimes > 40o C)

Mental status changes

Motor symptoms:

  • Muscular rigidity (generalised)
  • Dystonia
  • Akinesia

Autonomic symptoms:    

  • Tachycardia/arrhythmias
  • Labile blood pressure         
  • Tachypnea
  • Diaphoresis

Mutism, obtundation, and agita­tion.
Precipitating factors

Antipsychotics (typical and atypical)

Antiemetics (ex: Promethazine, Metoclopramide) 

Withdrawal of Antiparkinsonian drugs (dopamine agonists) 

Infection 

Surgery
Investigations

Elevated WBC count, creatinine phosphokinase (CPK), myoglobin, and liver enzymes.

Myoglobinuria may be seen in patients who develop acute renal failure.
Treatment 
  • Stop neuroleptic agents and start dopaminergic agonists
  • Supportive care (hydration, cooling)
  • Dantrolene or Bromocriptine
  • Amantadine may be used in some cases.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy may also be used. 

Related Pearl: Non extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotics

 

Typical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Chlorpromazine Corneal & lenticular deposits, vortex keratopathy, obstructive jaundice
Thioridazine Irreversible retinal pigmentation, QT prolongation

 

Atypical antipsychotics

Drug Side effects
Clozapine Agranulocytosis, metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain, wet pillow syndrome (excessive night time drooling)
Olanzapine Metabolic syndrome, diabetes, weight gain
Quetiapine Cataract
Ziprasidone QT prolongation
Amisulpride Hyperprolactinemia
Aripiprazole Hypoprolactinemia 

Related Pearl: Extrapyramidal side effects of antipsychotic drugs

Adverse reactions
Time of onset
Features
Treatment
Acute dystonia
1 to 5 days
Spasm of muscles of tongue, face, neck, back
Diphenhydramine or benztropine
Akathisia
5 to 60 days
Restlessness
Propranolol, lorazepam, diphenhydramine, benztropine
Parkinsonism
5 to 30 days
Bradykinesia, rigidity, tremors
Dose reduction, change medication, antiparkinsonian agents
Tardive dyskinesia
Months to years
Orofacial dyskinesia (may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation)
VMAT-2 inhibitors valbenazine and deutetrabenazine
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
Weeks to months
Extreme rigidity, fever, unstable blood pressure
Dantrolene

questions.text: An anxious mother brings her 2-month-old baby saying that her baby defecates after every feed. This reflex is called as
questions.solution:
The reflex given in the clinical scenario is a gastrocolic reflex. In this reflex, distension of the stomach by food results in the evacuation of the colon. This reflex is mainly transmitted by the autonomic nervous system through prevertebral sympathetic ganglia.

Other options:

Option A- When food leaves the stomach, the passage of chyme through the ileocecal valve increases due to vigorous peristalsis. This forces the chyme into the cecum. This is called gastroileal reflex.

Option B- Entry of food into the small intestine and colon results in the inhibition of gastric motility and gastric secretions. This is called enterogastric reflex.

Option C- Entry of chyme into the colon results in the inhibition of emptying of ileal contents into the colon. This is called colonoileal reflex.

Related Pearl: Factors regulating gastric emptying

Factors that Increase gastric emptying

Factors that Decrease gastric emptying

Distension of the stomach

Distension of the duodenum

Food rich in carbohydrate

Food rich in fats > proteins

Stimulation of parasympathetic nervous system

Stimulation of sympathetic nervous system

 

Presence of fat in duodenum

 

High acidity (low pH) of the duodenal chyme

Isotonic chyme

Hypertonic >>hypotonic duodenal content

 

Breakdown products of protein digestion in the duodenum

 

Presence of any irritation in the duodenal mucosa

Gastrin

CCK, Secretin, GIP

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy who presented to the district hospital with HIV-positive status was to be started on antiretroviral therapy (ART). The fixed-dose combination of drugs preferred to initiate ART for him is:
questions.solution:
The fixed-dose combination of drugs preferred to start antiretroviral therapy (ART) for him is tenofovir + lamivudine + dolutegravir (TLD regimen).

The first-line ART for HIV-positive patients with age >10 years and weight >30kg should consist of an NRTI (Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors) backbone, preferably tenofovir (300mg) + lamivudine (300mg), and one INSTI ( integrase strand transfer inhibitors ), preferably dolutegravir (50mg). TLD regimen is given as fixed-dose combination in a single pill once a day, at a fixed time every day.

WHO recommends use of dolutegravir (DTG) in both first and second-line ART, including during pregnancy and tuberculosis co-treatment, and for children.

The drugs used for ART are:

  • Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs)
    • Abacavir (ABC)
    • Didanosine (ddl)
    • Emtricitabine (FTC)
    • Lamivudine (3TC)
    • Stavudine (d4T)
    • Zidovudine (AZT)
  • Nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NtRTls)
    • Tenofovir (TDF)
  • Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase Inhibitors (NNRTls)
    • Efavirenz (EFV)
    • Etravirine (ETV)
    • Nevirapine (NVP)
  • Protease Inhibitors (PIs)
    • Atazanavir + ritonavir (ATV/r)
    • Darunavir + ritonavir (DRV)r)
    • Fos-amprenavir + ritonavir (FPV/r)
    • lndinavir + ritonavir (IDV/r)
    • Lopinavir/ritonavir (LPV/r)
    • Saquinavir + ritonavir (SQVtr)
  • lntegrase strand transfer inhibitors (INSTls) 
    • Raltegravir (RAL)

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

TDF - Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 

3TC - Lamivudine 

FTC - Emtricitabine 

DTG - Dolutegravir 

ATV/r - Atazanavir + ritonavir 

DRV/r - Darunavir + ritonavir 

LPV/r - Lopinavir + ritonavir 

RAL - Raltegravir 

AZT - Zidovudine 

ABC - Abacavir

questions.text:
Given below is the procedure done under 'Nalgonda technique'. What is the purpose of this technique?
Add lime + alum
↓
Flocculation
↓
Sedimentation
↓
Filtration

choices.text: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal
Air floatation of grains to remove ergot

questions.solution:
The Nalgonda technique is used for the defluoridation of water, which involves the addition of lime and alum followed by flocculation, sedimentation, and filtration.

Fluorosis occurs when drinking water contains excess amounts of fluorine, in the range of 3-5mg/L. It is endemic to certain parts of India like Andhra Pradesh (Nellore, Prakasam), Telangana(Nalgonda), Punjab, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, and Tamil Nadu. 

Symptoms correspond to levels of fluoride intake:

  • Dental fluorosis (1.5mg/L): Occurs if excess fluoride is ingested during the period of tooth calcification, i.e. in the first 7 years of life. It is best seen on the upper incisors and almost exclusively affects permanent teeth. It causes mottling of dental enamel, the appearance of chalky-white, and dull patches on the teeth in the early stages. The white spots progressively turn yellow and then brown-black. The loss of enamel gives a  corroded appearance.
  • Skeletal fluorosis (3-6mg/L): Occurs due to the heavy deposition of fluoride in the skeleton. Fluorosis stimulates osteoblastic activity, and fluorapatite crystals are laid down in bone. These are usually resistant to secondary osteoclastic resorption. This leads to calcium retention, osteosclerosis, and osteophytosis. Ossification of ligaments and fascial attachments is characteristic.
  • Crippling fluorosis (>10mg/L): Can lead to permanent disability. 

Genu valgum and osteoporosis of the lower limb are seen in a newer form of fluorosis in Tamil Nadu and Andhra Pradesh. It is seen in people consuming jawar (sorghum), as it promotes greater retention of ingested fluoride.

The given images show dental fluorosis and skeletal fluorosis (interosseous-membrane-calcification), respectively:

 

Interventions for Fluorosis 

  • Change the drinking water source with a lower fluoride content (0.5 to 0.8 mg/L). Running surface water contains lower quantities of fluorides than groundwater sources.
  • The National Environmental Engineering Research Institute, Nagpur, developed a technique for removing fluoride by a chemical treatment called the Nalgonda technique. 
  • Fluoride supplements should not be prescribed for children who drink fluoridated water.
  • The use of fluoride toothpaste in areas of endemic fluorosis is not recommended for children up to 6 years of age

Other options:

Option A: Controlled superchlorination of water is the addition of large amounts of chlorine to the water, for disinfection. The excess is later removed. It is done for heavily polluted water with fluctuating quality.

Option C: Steeping pulses in hot water for toxin removal is done for Lathyrism. The toxin beta oxalyl amino alanine, in its crystalline form, is water-soluble. The pulse is soaked in boiling water for 2 hours, and the water is drained off completely. It is then washed with clean water and dried. 

Option D: Air floatation of grains is done to remove ergot, which is a field fungus. It can be removed by floating the grains in 20% saltwater, air floatation, or hand-picking.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, the following finding is noted on the lips and in the buccal mucosa. An endoscopic study revealed multiple hamartomatous polyps in the intestine. Which of the following malignancies are associated with this condition?

1) Breast

2) Cervix

3) Pancreas

4) Testicles

5) Thyroid
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome and all the malignancies mentioned above (1, 2, 3, 4, and 5) can be associated with this condition.

Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract most commonly in the small intestine and melanosis of the mouth and the lips.

It germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11/ liver kinase B1 (STK11/LKB1) gene on chromosome 19.

The most common presenting symptom is recurrent colicky abdominal pain which is usually the result of an underlying intussusception. This might be associated with the presence of a palpable mass in the lower abdomen.

Rarely, patients may present with features of anaemia due to haemorrhage as a result of auto-amputation of the polyps occurs.

It is also associated with hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract, hyperpigmentation (small, brown or black spots) of the buccal mucosa, lips, perianal skin, and digits, and an increased risk for cancer of the intestinal tract and extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, thyroid ,pancreas, cervix and testicles.

Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding or intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman delivered a baby vaginally, without any complications. After birth, the placenta was expelled and it was found that the cord was attached to the membranes and the cord vessels were traversing between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. Identify the abnormal placenta.
questions.solution:
The abnormal placenta shown in the image is a velamentous placenta as the cord is attached to the membranes.

The umbilical cord is usually attached at or near the center of the placenta at term.

The cord is attached to the membranes in the case of velamentous placenta. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination. 

Management-

  • If fetal bleeding occurs, urgent delivery is done either vaginally or by cesarean section. The infant’s hemoglobin levels should be tested and if necessary, blood transfusion can also be done.
  • If the baby is dead, vaginal delivery is allowed to occur.

The below image shows velamentous placenta:

 When velamentous placenta is associated with vasa previa, there is an increased chance of rupture of vessels and bleeding:

Option A- Circumvallate placenta is a type of placenta extrachorialis. There is a smaller chorionic plate as compared to the basal plate. The amnion and chorion fold and roll back on themselves to form a ring that is reflected centrally. This leaves a rim of placental tissue exposed extrachorially. There is an increased chance of abortions, hydrorrhea gravidarum, antepartum hemorrhage, growth retardation of the fetus, preterm delivery, and retained placenta and membranes. 

The below image shows circumvallate placenta:

Option B- Battledore placenta, where the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a Previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

The below image shows battledore placenta:

Option D- Succenturiate placenta is characterized by the presence of one or more small lobes of placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins. A leash of blood vessels connects these accessory cotyledons to the main placenta. If these vessels are absent, then it is called placenta spuria. If this lobe is retained postpartum, there can be primary or secondary postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution of uterus, uterine sepsis, polyp formation. 

The below image shows succenturiate placenta:

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with dementia and gait difficulties along with episodes of urinary incontinence. Physical examination is notable for magnetic gait. There is no papilledema. An MRI brain demonstrates ventricular enlargement. After a serial lumbar puncture, his gait significantly improves. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The triad of dementia, ataxia, and urinary incontinence, along with the other clinical features and MRI showing enlarged ventricles, is highly suggestive of normal-pressure hydrocephalus. Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting is preferred in this condition.

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a reversible cause of dementia. It is caused by obstruction to the normal CSF flow in the cerebral convexity and delayed absorption into the venous system.

Clinical features of NPH triad:

  • ataxia (magnetic gait is described as slow and unsteady turns that are slow, broad-based, and short-stepped)
  • dementia
  • urinary incontinence

Papilloedema is not seen.

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculo-peritoneal shunting- It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options: 

Idiopathic intracranial hypertension presents with transient vision loss, headache, and papilledema. Medical therapy includes acetazolamide and furosemide. Topiramate is also used due to carbonic anhydrase inhibitor activity. Surgical therapy includes optic nerve sheath decompression (or optic nerve sheath fenestration) and CSF shunting procedures.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilious vomiting. An abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the presence of a double bubble sign which is a feature of the duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is associated with prematurity, Down’s syndrome, and polyhydramnios.

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. This is because the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases. Abdominal radiographs also show the double-bubble sign if done before orogastric tube decompression. It is treated by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis will show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble /single bubble. It is seen at 2-8 weeks of life, more commonly in boys. It presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting which can lead to hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Visible gastric peristalsis can also be observed.

Option B: Jejunal atresia on an abdominal radiograph shows the triple bubble sign. It is the most common type of gastrointestinal atresia. Presenting features include bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium.

Option D:  Colonic atresia is the least common type of intestinal atresia. A plain radiograph shows multiple dilated bowel loops, but differentiation between small and large bowel is not possible in neonates. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis. The contrast does not pass proximally to the sigmoid colon as seen in the image.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: As an anesthesia consultant, you're planning to insert a central venous line for a patient requiring inotropes and parenteral nutrition for a prolonged period. Which of the following veins will you choose so as to have reduced long-term complications?
questions.solution:
Among the given options subclavian is the best vein for long-term cannulation.

The usual complications of prolonged cannulations include line infection, sepsis, air or thrombus embolism, arrhythmias, hematoma, hemothorax, and thrombosis.

As compared to cannulation of other veins, subclavian vein cannulation has a reduced risk of complications due to prolonged cannulations. It is, however, associated with a maximum risk of pneumothorax.

Other options:

Option B- The internal jugular vein on the right side is better than the left side. Left-sided insertion has an increased risk of pleural effusion and chylothorax.

Option C- The external jugular vein is less preferred because it enters at an acute angle into chest veins, hence there are decreased chances of easy access.

Option D- Femoral veins are less preferred for long-term usage because they are associated with frequent line-related sepsis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with chronic neck pain. He has a short neck and a limited range of neck movements. On examination, lateral bending movements are very restricted. An X-ray of the neck is taken. Which of the following pathognomonic radiological signs is seen in this X-ray?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is highly suggestive of Klippel-Feil syndrome. The pathognomonic radiological sign seen in the X-ray is the wasp-waist sign. The given X-ray shows the fusion of cervical vertebrae.

Klippel-Feil syndrome is a developmental disorder caused by a failure of normal segmentation of the cervical somites during the 3rd to 8th week of embryogenesis. There is an important association with fetal alcohol syndrome. This results in a congenital fusion of at least 2 cervical vertebrae, sometimes a block of cervical vertebrae, and rarely the entire cervical spine.

In Klippel-Feil syndrome, a classical clinical triad of short neck, low posterior hairline, and limited range neck mobility is seen. Congenital fusion of cervical segments can occur at any level, but most cases(75%) occur in the upper cervical spine.

Associated anomalies are,

  • Scoliosis in 60% of patients
  • Renal abnormalities (35%)
  • Congenital heart diseases, most commonly ventricular septal defect(VSD) (14%)
  • Deafness (30%)
  • Sprengel deformity (30%)
  • Hand anomalies such as syndactyly, thumb hypoplasia, and extra digits.

Sprengel deformity, ‘Sprengel’s shoulder’ or congenital elevation of the scapula is an anomaly of the shoulder girdle that is associated altered position and anatomy of the scapula. The deformity is usually associated with muscle hypoplasia or atrophy, and a combination of these factors results in disfigurement and functional limitation of the shoulder.

Symptoms present in the second or third decades, not from the fused segments but from the adjacent mobile segments. Lateral bending movements are very restricted. There may be pain due to joint hypermobility or neurological symptoms from instability.

Treatment- Mandatory ultrasound evaluation of the renal system should be done. Asymptomatic patients are advised to avoid contact sports because sudden catastrophic neurological compromise can occur after minor trauma. Symptomatic children may need cervical fusion.

Imaging- X-rays and computed tomography(CT) scans reveal fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae.

The wasp-waist sign is a radiographic appearance seen in patients with Klippel-Feil syndrome. It results from the fusion of the vertebral bodies. The anteroposterior diameter at the level of the affected disco-vertebral joint is smaller than the diameter of the unaffected vertebrae above and below. This resembles the constriction between the thorax and abdomen of a wasp.

The image below shows a patient with Klippel-Feil syndrome and Sprengel deformity- short neck and elevation of right scapula. He also has thoracolumbar deformity.

 

Other options-

Option A- Bamboo spine is a pathognomonic radiographic feature seen in ankylosing spondylitis. It occurs as a result of vertebral body fusion by marginal syndesmophytes. There may be a fusion of the posterior vertebral elements as well. A bamboo spine typically involves the thoracolumbar and/or lumbosacral junctions and not the cervical spine.

 

Option B- Fish vertebra, also known as codfish vertebra, refers to the biconcave appearance of vertebrae. It is especially seen in the lumbar vertebrae. It is seen in osteoporosis, sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis, homocystinuria, renal osteodystrophy, osteogenesis imperfecta, osteomalacia, and rarely in thalassemia major.

 

Option C- The winking owl sign,  also called the absent pedicle sign, is seen on a plain radiograph of the spine when a pedicle is absent. The causes are spinal metastases, intraspinal malignancies, tuberculosis, congenital absence of a pedicle, neurofibromatosis, lymphoma, and radiation therapy.

Related Pearl: Classical Radiological Appearance of Bone Tumors

RADIOLOGICAL APPEARANCE 

TUMORS

Sunray appearance / Codman’s triangle

Osteosarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion)

Onion peel appearance 

Ewing’s sarcoma (but can be seen in any malignant lesion or chronic osteomyelitis)

Soap bubble appearance 

Giant cell tumor, adamantinoma 

Ground glass appearance / Shepherd's

crook deformity 

Fibrous dysplasia 

Patchy calcification 

Chondrogenic tumors (chondrosarcoma and chondroblastoma)

Popcorn, punctate or comma-shaped calcification

Chondrosarcoma 

Stippled or Punctate calcification

Chondroblastoma 

Homogeneous calcification 

Osteogenic tumors (osteosarcoma)

Fallen fragment / Trap door sign

Simple bone cyst

Double-density fluid levels and intra-lesional septation

Aneurysmal bone cyst

Winking owl sign

Vertebral metastasis 

Polka dot sign / Corduroy / Jailhouse sign

Vertebral hemangioma

Moth eaten bone

Multiple myeloma

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with fever, chills, and tender inguinal lymphadenopathy. Smears prepared from the discharge of these swellings revealed bacteria with bipolar staining. Which stain was used to prepare these smears?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of fever, chills, tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, and a smear showing bipolar staining of bacteria is highly suggestive of bubonic plague caused by Yersinia pestis. The stain used for this organism is the Wayson stain containing methylene blue.

Plague is a zoonotic disease caused by Yersinia pestis. It is a gram-negative, non-motile, coccobacillus. The reservoirs of infection are wild rodents like field mice, gerbils, skunks, etc. In India, the gerbil (Tatera indica) is the main reservoir. The important vector of plague is rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis).

Humans acquire the disease by the bite of an infected flea, by direct contact with the tissues of the infected animal, or by droplet infection from cases of pneumonic plague. 

Human plague mainly presents as:

Bubonic plague- This is the most common type of disease. The patient develops a sudden fever, chills, headache, and painful lymphadenitis. Within a few days, the lymph nodes in the groin, axilla, or neck enlarge and are called buboes. This is followed by the suppuration of the buboes. Bubonic plague cannot spread from person to person as the bacilli are locked up in the buboes and do not find a way or easy exit.

Pneumonic plague- It develops as a complication of bubonic-septicemic plague. 

Septicemic plague- It occurs when the infection spreads to the blood.

Laboratory diagnosis- Microscopy reveals bacteria that show characteristic bipolar staining or safety pin appearance when stained with Wayson's stain. Antibodies to the F1 antigen of the bacteria can also be demonstrated by passive hemagglutination. PCR is used for a rapid presumptive diagnosis.

Treatment- Streptomycin, doxycycline, and chloramphenicol can be used.

Other options:

Options B & D- Albert's and Neisser's stains are used to stain Corynebacterium diphtheriae. They show the bacteria with metachromatic granules arranged in chinese-letter or cuneiform pattern.

Option C- Warthin-starry stain is used to stain Bartonella henselae which causes cat-scratch disease.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms
Masson’s Fontana Melanin and argentaffin Cells
Gomori Methenamine Silver Fungi
Luxol Fast Blue (LFB) Myelin
Phosphotungstic Acid-hematoxylin Cross striations of skeletal muscle, fibrin
Toluidine blue Mast cells
Warthin–Starry Helicobacter pylori, spirochetes
Van Gieson Collagen fibres
Mucicarmine Mucin, Cryptococcus capsule

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a high-speed two-wheeler motor vehicle accident. Blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drips from both nostrils which increases on leaning forward. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and the pterygoid plate. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?

CT: Computed tomography
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a Le-Fort II fracture of the maxilla. 

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture. It is characterized by a fracture line that passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and pterygoid plates.

Clinically, patients present after high-speed trauma to the face. They may present with a visible deformity or elongation of the midface. There is malocclusion of teeth on attempting to bite. Palpation may reveal an unusually mobile maxilla. It may be associated with CSF(cerebrospinal fluid) rhinorrhea due to injury to the cribriform plate. 

Diagnosis requires an X-ray or CT scan, wherein findings such as hanging maxilla are present. 

Treatment required fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following procedures requires the consent of both spouses?
questions.solution:
Artificial insemination by a donor (AID) requires the consent of both the wife and the husband. If the consent is not obtained from the husband, he can proceed to file a case against the doctor, as well as a divorce from his wife.

Other options:
Options A and D- Vasectomy and tubectomy are sterilization procedures that require the written consent of only the person undergoing the procedure.

Option C: Medical termination of pregnancy does not require the consent of the husband.
The consent of the woman is mandatory for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone.

Related Pearl: Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act - MTP Act 1971

MTP Act with 2021 amendments 

Indications:

  • Therapeutic - to save the life of the mother
  • Eugenic - to prevent the risk of the child being born with serious mental or physical abnormality i.e. first-trimester viral infections, teratogenic drug intake, radiation exposure
  • Humanitarian - pregnancy resulted from rape or incest
  • Social - pregnancy resulted from failure of contraceptives 

Rules:

  • Only a registered medical practitioner who is qualified (one who has assisted in the performance of 25 cases of MTP in a recognized hospital) can terminate a pregnancy.
  • MTP should be carried out in a government or government-recognized hospital. Private hospitals may take up MTP if they obtain a license from the chief medical officer of the district.
  • The termination of pregnancy by a person, who is not a registered medical practitioner (the person concerned), or in an unrecognised hospital (administrative head) shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term not less than 2 years, but which may extend to 7 years. 

Consent:

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Confidentiality:

A register for recording the details of MTP must be kept for at least 5 years. The patient's name must not be entered, only the reference number is used. Unlawful disclosure of patient's details is punishable with 1-year imprisonment ± fine.

questions.text:
Match the type of collagen with the associated collagen defect disorder.
Types of collagen Collagen defect disorders

1. Type I

 A- Stickler syndrome

2. Type II

 B- Alport syndrome

3. Type III

C- Ehler Danlos syndrome

4. Type IV

 D- Osteogenesis imperfecta
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-C, 4-B.

Types of collagen Collagen defect disorders

1. Type I

 D- Osteogenesis imperfecta

2. Type II

 A- Stickler syndrome

3. Type III

C- Ehler Danlos syndrome

4. Type IV

 B- Alport syndrome

Osteogenesis imperfecta is inherited as a dominant trait. It is the result of a mutation that results in the replacement of a single glycine residue by cysteine in Type I collagen. The result is brittle bones leading to multiple fractures and skeletal deformities.

Stickler syndrome results due to a defect in type II collagen and is characterized by skeletal changes, orofacial abnormalities, and auditory abnormalities.

Ehler-Danlos syndrome is due to defective Type III collagen formation due to defective lysyl oxidase or lysyl hydroxylase. It is characterized by the weakening of collagen, loose skin, and hypermobile and lax joints. Hyperextensibility of skin and joints are the hallmark of this condition.

Alport syndrome is due to a defect in type IV collagen. It is characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, anterior lenticonus, and renal insufficiency.

Related Pearl: Types of Collagen

Collagen subtypes    Location   

Associated disease 
Type 1

Dermis 

Bone 

Tendons 

Ligaments

Dentin

Cornea

Blood Vessels 

Scar tissue

Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 
Type 2

Cartilage 

Vitreous humor 

Nucleus pulposus

  Stickler syndrome
Type 3

Skin 

Lung 

Intestines 

Blood Vessels 

Bone marrow 

Lymphatics 

Granulation tissue

Ehler-Danlos syndrome  
Type 4

Basement membrane 

 		 Alport syndrome 
Type 7

Dermo-epidermal junction

 Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the muscle shown acting in the given graphic ?
questions.solution:
The muscle acting in the given graphic is the platysma which is innervated by the cervical branch of the facial nerve.

The platysma is a broadsheet of muscle in the anterior aspect of the neck.

Origin- It arises from the fascia covering the upper parts of pectoralis major and deltoid. Its fibres cross the clavicle and ascend medially in the side of the neck. The interlacing of the anterior fibres from the contralateral muscle occurs in the midline, below, and behind the symphysis menti.

Attachment- The fibres attach to the symphysis menti, the lower border of the mandible, the lower lip, or cross the mandible to attach to skin and subcutaneous tissue of the lower face.

Clinical significance- During neck dissection in the subplatysmal plane, there should be a careful elevation of a myocutaneous flap with the platysma and its blood supply. This reduces the risk of skin necrosis and improves wound healing.

Vascular supply- Submental branch of the facial artery and the suprascapular artery supply the platysma. The suprascapular artery is derived from the thyrocervical trunk of the subclavian artery.

Nerve supply- It is innervated by the cervical branch of the facial nerve. This branch descends close to the angle of the mandible, on the deep surface of the muscle and supplies it.

Actions- Contraction of the platysma produces tense, oblique ridges in the skin of the neck. This reduces the concavity between the jaw and the side of the neck. Platysma may assist in depressing the mandible. Due to its labial and modiolar attachments, it can draw down the lower lip and corners of the mouth in expressions of horror or surprise.

Other options:

Option A- The ansa cervicalis is a part of the cervical plexus. It supplies the infrahyoid muscles (sternohyoid, omohyoid, sternothyroid), except the thyrohyoid which is supplied by the first cervical spinal nerve.

Option B- The hypoglossal nerve provides motor branches to all the extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except the palatoglossus), which are genioglossus, hyoglossus and styloglossus.

Option D- The first cervical spinal nerve is a branch of the hypoglossal nerve and supplies the thyrohyoid muscle.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

Arch Nerve Skeletal derivatives Pouch Derivatives Muscle Derivatives Artery 

1st (mandibular arch)

  • Incus
  • Malleus
  • Anterior ligament of malleus
  • Spine of sphenoid
  • Sphenomandibular ligament 
  • Auditory tube
  • Middle ear cavity 
  • Tensor tympani
  • Muscles of mastication 
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor veli palatini
  • Maxillary artery

2nd (hyoid arch)

  • Stapes
  • Styloid process (temporal)
  • Lesser cornu and upper hyoid
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Palatine tonsil
  • Tonsillar fossa 
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid 
  • Facial Muscles (Buccinator, Platysma, Posterior belly of digastric)
  • Stapedial artery
  • Hyoid artery
3rd Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Greater cornu of hyoid
  • Lower part of hyoid body
  • Inferior parathyroids
  • Thymus 
  • Stylopharyngeus
  • Common carotid
  • Proximal internal carotid arteries 
4th Superior laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage 
  • Superior parathyroids,
  • Parafollicular C cells of Thyroid (from ultimobranchial body)
 
  • Pharyngeal muscles
  • Larynx -Cricothyroid
  • Levator veli palatini
  • Right side: Right subclavian artery (proximal portion)
  • Left side: Arch of the aorta from the left common carotid to the left subclavian arteries
6th Recurrent laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Arytenoid cartilages
 		  
  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle)
  • Right side: right pulmonary artery 
  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A patient with diagnosed peptic ulcer disease develops sudden intense abdominal pain and distension. A plain supine x-ray of his abdomen is shown below. What is the characteristic sign seen in the given x-ray?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and x-ray image are suggestive of pneumoperitoneum, and the characteristic sign seen in the x-ray is Rigler's sign or double-wall sign. The inner mucosal and outer serosal layers of the bowel wall are enhanced due to the presence of air on both sides of the bowel lumen. 

Pneumoperitoneum refers to air within the peritoneal cavity. Radiological signs include:

  • Bowel related signs
    • Double-wall sign (also known as Rigler's sign): Both the outer and inner walls of the bowel are visible.
    • Telltale triangle sign (also known as triangle sign): A radiolucent triangle of gas between three loops of bowel or between two loops of bowel and the abdominal wall.
  • Peritoneal ligament related signs
    • Football sign -the abdominal cavity is outlined by gas from a perforated viscus, seen in massive pneumoperitoneum.
    • Falciform ligament sign - Falciform or medial umbilical ligaments may be seen due to free gas on either side of the ligaments. 
    • Lateral umbilical ligament sign (also known as inverted "V" sign) - Free gas routines the lateral umbilical ligament.
  • Right upper quadrant signs
    • Morison's pouch sign - a triangular area of gas in the right upper quadrant, usually bound by the 11th rib in the right upper quadrant in the area of Morrison's pouch.
    • Cupola sign - Gas under the right and left hemidiaphragm joining in the midline. Seen on chest X-ray.

Other options:

Option A - The spinnaker-sail sign (or angel wing sign) is characteristic of a pneumomediastinum in neonates. Both the lobes of the thymus are lifted and displaced laterally due to the air in the mediastinum. A wedge-shaped opacity is created extending into the superior mediastinum. 

Option B - Cupola sign is also seen in pneumoperitoneum. It refers to the gas accumulated under the diaphragm in the midline underneath the central tendon. It is seen in supine films of abdominal x-ray. 

Option D - Stepladder sign (or concertina effect) is seen in small intestinal obstruction. It represents the gas-fluid distended loops stacked upon each other, best appreciated in erect abdomen x-ray.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with sudden, progressive, painless loss of vision in the right eye. There was no history of associated photopsia. On examination, the retina appeared convex and detached with no evidence of breaks. Which among the following signs is likely to be present?
questions.solution:
The case is suggestive of serous or exudative retinal detachment, and the presence of shifting fluid is a hallmark feature.

Exudative RD is characterized by the accumulation of fluid beneath the retina in the absence of a retinal break or traction. Fluid leaks outside the vessels and accumulates under the retina. RD does not occur as long as the retinal pigment epithelium is pumping the leaking fluid into the choroidal circulation. The causes include:

  • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
  • Choroidal tumors like melanoma
  • Toxemia of pregnancy
  • Central serous retinopathy
  • Coats disease

Patients may present with painless progressive visual field defects without photopsia. Floaters may be present if there is an associated vitritis. Clinical signs include:

  • Convex configuration of the retinal detachment, with a smooth surface
  • Detached retina is very mobile
  • Shifting fluid sign- Subretinal fluid detaches the area of the retina under which it accumulates. In the upright position, it collects under the inferior retina. But in the supine position, the inferior retina flattens, the fluid shifts posteriorly which detaches the superior retina.
  • The cause of the RD may be apparent. 
  • Leopard spots- Scattered areas of clumped subretinal pigment may be seen after the detachment has flattened.

Other options:

Options B and C: Relative afferent pupillary defect and Schaffer sign are seen in rhegmatogenous RD. Schaffer's sign refers to tobacco dust appearance in anterior vitreous with substantial vitreous blood or inflammatory cells. 

Option D- Reduced retinal mobility is seen in tractional retinal detachment.

questions.text: A young woman had been to a beach for vacation. The next day, she developed the following skin lesions which were very itchy. On examination, the lesions are raised. There were no lesions on the face. She avoided sun exposure for the next 4-5 days and the lesions disappeared. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of raised itchy skin lesions that occur after sun exposure but spare the face and disappear after avoiding sun exposure is suggestive of polymorphic light eruptions. 

It is a recurrent, delayed‐type hypersensitivity (type IV) to sunlight (or artificial ultraviolet rays source) that resolves without scarring. Itchy eruptions appear hours after exposure to the sun. If the patient is exposed to the sun in mid-day, lesions might appear in the night or the following day. Sparing of the face and dorsal aspect of hands is usually seen. This is due to tolerance induced by repeated perennial ultraviolet radiation exposure. On avoiding sun exposure, the lesions disappear within days to weeks.

Other options:

Option A: Sunburn usually presents as painful erythema. It may occur in any sun-exposed areas like the face, hands, etc. It resolves in three to seven days. Scaling, desquamation, and tanning can be seen four to seven days after exposure.

Option B: Heat contact urticaria is one of the rarest forms of inducible urticaria. Localized warming of skin at temperatures from 38 to 44°C for 2–5 min induces wealing at the test site. It usually lasts for an hour.

Option C: In solar urticaria, weals develop within minutes of exposure to sunlight. On avoiding the sun, they disappear within 2 hours.
